prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6 H2S2 @ 265.368 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: These observations cover the H2S2 line at 265.368 GHz and two other H2S2 lines centered at 266.2 and 266.4 GHz with higher values of Eu at the upper sideband. At the same time, the H2S2 line at 251.424 and two other H2S2 lines centered at 252.2 and 252.4 with higher values of Eu are observed at the lower sideband. A total of 6 HS2 transitions are also covered in this science goal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have used IRAS16293-2422 A as reference for the expected peak line flux calculations. The central radial velocity of this source is 3.2 km/s (Jorgensen et al. 2011) and its excitation temperature is ~100 K (Ceccarelli et al. 2000). The detected lines toward this source have an average FWHM of 2,6km/s (Jorgensen et al. 2011), with a derived H2S abundance of 5E-7 (Wakelam et al. 2004). By using our APEX observations, we have extracted an upper limit for the H2S2 and HS2 abundance of 1.5% relative to H2S toward IRAS16293-2422. To estimate the expected peak line fluxes for the rotational transitions, we have assumed a conservative abundance of 1% relative to H2S, and we have combined these data with the predictions made by H. Mueller for H2S2 and those of HS2 provided by the Cologne Database for Molecular Spectroscopy. In order to clearly detect and identify new species, a signal to noise (S/N) ratio of 6 is usually required, although a S/N ratio of 3 may be considered a detection. Given the expected peak line flux for the H2S2 transition at 265,368 GHz (the representative frequency of this science goal) at the upper sideband, we need a sensitivity of 4,69 mJy to detect this transition with a S/N = 6 . Seven more narrow spectral windows have been defined targeting up to five more H2S2 transitions and six HS2 transitions. Table 1 in the scientific justification presents the H2S2 transitions expected to be detected with a S/N ratio higher than 3 for the requested rms. The bandwidth used for sensitivity is slightly wider (0,2 km/s) than the requested spectral resolution (see below) to optimize the observing time.

In this particular science goal, we plan to detect one H2S2 transition at 265,368 GHz (the representative frequency of the science goal) at the upper sideband. According to our intensities estimates, with a sensitivity of 4,69 mJy we would detect this transition with a S/N = 6 (see above). Selecting another three spectral windows within the same baseband in the upper sideband allow us to cover two more H2S2 transitions with higher values of Eu and lower S/N ratios in two separate spectral windows, and two unresolved HS2 transitions in the remaining spectral window. For these spectral windows, a good spectral resolution will prevent the dilution of the H2S2 line flux in a broader spectral range, increasing the probability of detection of these lines, so a correlator mode with 58.594 MHz bandwidth (the narrowest possible bandwidth, so we can observe all the expected transitions in the same baseband) and a spectral resolution of 0.138 km/s has been chosen for each spectral window, but, in order to keep the data rate below 12 MB/s, an spectral average of 2 has been selected, leading to a spectral resolution of 0,159 km/s at the representative frequency. This way, we have one baseband in the upper sideband dedicated to continuum observation with a worse spectral resolution, to be used for the upper sideband calibration.
At the same time, we plan to detect one H2S2 transition at 251,424 GHz at the lower sideband. We have selected three other spectral windows in the same baseband to cover two more H2S2 transitions with higher values of Eu and lower S/N ratios, and two more pairs of unresolved HS2 transitions. As in the upper sideband, a good spectral resolution will prevent the dilution of the H2S2 line flux in a broader spectral range, increasing the probability of detection of these lines, so a correlator mode with 58.594 MHz bandwidth and a spectral resolution of 0.145 km/s has been chosen for each spectral window, but, in order to keep the data rate below 12 MB/s, an spectral average of 2 has been selected, leading to a spectral resolution of 0,168 km/s. With this configuration, we have also one baseband in the lower sideband dedicated to continuum observation with a worse spectral resolution, to be used for the lower sideband calibration.
A data rate higher than 6 MB/s is needed to cover all the desired transitions. The observing time requested for this science goal is 1.31 hrs. None non-standard choices need to be justified.

The IRAS16293-2422 binary system has an angular size of about 8 arcseconds. Therefore, the requested largest angular scale is 8 arcseconds. The emission of the sulfur species is expected to come from the inner hot cores, with an angular size of 2" (Wakelam et al. 2004). Since we look for the detection of new molecules, we do not need to spatially resolve the emission within the hot corinos, so the angular resolution yielded with the most compact 12m-Array configuration is enough for every science goal. The angular resolution requested is thus 1.4 arcseconds, corresponding to the synthesized beamsize of the most compact 12m-Array configuration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 H2S2 @ 293.3 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: These observations cover the H2S2 line at 293.256 GHz with Eu= 50 K, and two other lines at 294.1 GHz and 294.2 GHz with Eu=50 K. At the same time, the H2S2 line at 279.312 with Eu=44K, and two other lines at 280.2 and 280.3 with higher values of Eu are observed at the lower sideband. 4 HS2 transitions could also be observed with this science goal

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have used IRAS16293-2422 A as reference for the expected peak line flux calculations. The central radial velocity of this source is 3.2 km/s (Jorgensen et al. 2011) and its excitation temperature is ~100 K (Ceccarelli et al. 2000). The detected lines toward this source have an average FWHM of 2,6km/s (Jorgensen et al. 2011), with a derived H2S abundance of 5E-7 (Wakelam et al. 2004). By using our APEX observations, we have extracted an upper limit for the H2S2 and HS2 abundance of 1.5% relative to H2S toward IRAS16293-2422. To estimate the expected peak line fluxes for the rotational transitions, we have assumed a conservative abundance of 1% relative to H2S, and we have combined these data with the predictions made by H. Mueller for H2S2 and those of HS2 provided by the Cologne Database for Molecular Spectroscopy. In order to clearly detect and identify new species, a signal to noise (S/N) ratio of 6 is usually required, although a S/N ratio of 3 may be considered a detection. Given the expected peak line flux for the H2S2 transition at 293,256 GHz (the representative frequency of the science goal) at the upper sideband, a sensitivity of 4,85 mJy is needed to detect this transition with a S/N = 6 . Seven more narrow spectral windows have been defined targeting up to five more H2S2 transitions and four HS2 transitions. Table 1 in the scientific justification presents the H2S2 transitions expected to be detected with a S/N ratio higher than 3 for the requested rms. The bandwidth used for sensitivity is slightly wider (0,2 km/s) than the requested spectral resolution (see below) to optimize the observing time.

In this particular science goal, we plan to detect one H2S2 transition at 293,256 GHz (the representative frequency of the science goal) at the upper sideband. According to our intensities estimates, with a sensitivity of 4,85 mJy we would detect this transition with a S/N = 6 (see above). Selecting another three spectral windows within the same baseband in the upper sideband allow us to cover two more H2S2 transitions with similar values of Eu but lower S/N ratios in two separate spectral window, and two resolved HS2 transitions at 292.759 GHz in the remaining spectral window. For these spectral windows, a good spectral resolution will prevent the dilution of the H2S2 line flux in a broader spectral range, increasing the probability of detection of these lines. A correlator mode with 58.594 MHz bandwidth (the narrowest possible bandwidth, so we can observe all the expected transitions in the same baseband) and a spectral resolution of 0.124 km/s has been chosen for each spectral window, and a spectral average of 2 has been selected in order to keep the data rate below 12 MB/s, leading to a spectral resolution of 0,144 km/s at the representative frequency. This way, we have one baseband in the upper sideband dedicated to continuum observation with a worse spectral resolution, to be used for the upper sideband calibration.
At the same time, we plan to detect one H2S2 transition at 279.312 GHz at the lower sideband. Another spectral window within the same baseband allow us to cover two resolved HS2 transitions at 280.023GHz, while two other spectral windows within the same baseband cover two more H2S2 transitions with higher values of Eu and lower S/N ratios. As in the upper sideband, a good spectral resolution will prevent the dilution of the H2S2 line flux in a broader spectral range, increasing the probability of detection of these lines. A correlator mode with 58.594 MHz bandwidth and a spectral resolution of 0.131 km/s has been chosen for each spectral window, and a spectral average of 2 has been selected in order to keep the data rate below 12 MB/s, leading to a spectral resolution of 0,151 km/s. With this configuration, we have also one baseband in the lower sideband dedicated to continuum observation with a worse spectral resolution, to be used for the lower sideband calibration.
A data rate higher than 6 MB/s is needed to cover all the desired transitions. The observing time requested for this science goal is 2.58 hrs. None non-standard choices need to be justified.

The IRAS16293-2422 binary system has an angular size of about 8 arcseconds. Therefore, the requested largest angular scale is 8 arcseconds. The emission of the sulfur species is expected to come from the inner hot cores, with an angular size of 2" (Wakelam et al. 2004). Since we look for the detection of new molecules, we do not need to spatially resolve the emission within the hot corinos, so the angular resolution yielded with the most compact 12m-Array configuration is enough for every science goal. The angular resolution requested is thus 1.2 arcseconds, corresponding to the synthesized beamsize of the most compact 12m-Array configuration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Sulfur is strongly depleted in dense clouds and circumstellar regions around YSOs. The missing sulfur might be locked onto the icy mantles of dust grains, initially in the form of H2S. Several S-bearing gas phase molecules such as H2S, SO2 or OCS have been observed in low-mass and high-mass hot cores, with abundances that cannot be explained with current gas-phase chemical models. Recent lab experiments have shown that energetic processing of H2S-bearing ices leads to efficient photolysis of H2S, with H2S2 and HS2 as the main products. We propose to observe several lines of H2S2 toward the hot corino around the IRAS16293-2422 low-mass protostar, where sulfur-bearing molecules are likely released by thermal or photo-desorption. These observations will confirm whether an important fraction of the missing sulfur is contained in H2S2 and HS2, and will provide key information about the poorly known chemical network of sulfur.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00352.S, Search for new sulfur-species formed in H2S-bearing, UV-photoprocessed ice mantles in circumstellar regions., Rafael Domenech, 2013.1.00352.S
